bcl:part.bcl:text: Ladders, Scaffolds and Temporary Work Platforms

bcl:definition.bcl:text: boom-supported means supported by an elevating device that telescopes, articulates, rotates or extends relative to the machine base or vehicle, so that the platform can be positioned completely beyond the base;
boatswain's chair, also known as a bosun's chair, means a seat attached to a suspended rope designed to accommodate one person in a sitting position;
elevating work platform means a movable work platform that self-elevates to overhead work locations;
movable work platform means a work platform that can be re-positioned during the course of the work;
permanent powered platform means a movable work platform that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is raised or lowered by other than manual means, and
is permanently installed on or attached to a building or structure;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: portable powered platform means a movable work platform that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is raised or lowered by other than manual means, and
is not permanently installed on or attached to a building or structure;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: scaffold means any temporary elevated work platform and its supporting structure used for supporting workers, materials or equipment;
self-propelled means the capability of an elevating work platform to travel under power with the primary controls on the work platform;
swing stage means a work platform that is raised and lowered by manual or powered hoisting equipment, supported by 2 or more suspension lines;
work platform means an elevated or suspended temporary work surface used for supporting workers and includes a scaffold and boatswain's chair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A ladder, window cleaner's belt or work platform must meet and be used in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicable CSA or ANSI standard in effect when the equipment or structure was manufactured, except as otherwise determined by the Board,
another standard acceptable to the Board, or
if there is no applicable standard under paragraphs (a) or (b), the requirements of a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In designing and installing a work platform, appropriate safety factors and minimum rated loads must be used in the materials and method of installation, in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: WCB Standard WPL 1, Design, Construction and Use of Wood Frame Scaffolds, 2004,
WCB Standard WPL 2, Design, Construction and Use of Crane Supported Work Platforms, 2004,
WCB Standard WPL 3, Safety Factor and Minimum Breaking Strength for Suspended Work Platforms and Associated Components, 2004, and
WCB Standard LDR 1, Job Built Ladders, 2004.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A ladder, window cleaner's belt, work platform and associated components must be inspected before use on each shift, and after any modification, and any condition that might endanger workers must be remedied before the equipment is used.
A manufactured portable ladder must be marked for the grade of material used to construct the ladder and the use for which the ladder is constructed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A portable ladder must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be placed on a firm and level surface, and
be of sufficient length to enable the safe performance of the work activity while being used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A portable non-self-supporting ladder must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as shown in Figure 13-1, be positioned so that the ladder is leaning against the vertical plane of support at an approximate angle of 75° when measured from the horizontal plane of support,
if the ladder provides access to or egress from an upper landing,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: project approximately 1 m (3 ft) above the upper landing, and
be sufficiently secured in place to ensure the stability of the ladder during access to or egress from the upper landing, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the ladder is not already secured in accordance with paragraph (b) (ii), be sufficiently secured in place to ensure the stability of the ladder during use if conditions exist that are likely to cause the ladder to be unstable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If work cannot be done from a ladder without hazard to a worker, a work platform must be provided.
A worker must not carry up or down a ladder, heavy or bulky objects or any other objects which may make ascent or descent unsafe.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Safe access must be provided to every work platform.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have sufficient strength to bear the load to be placed on it, and
be secured against separation from the supporting equipment, structure or surface to which it is attached.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Rigging and lines used to suspend or support work platforms must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have sufficient breaking strength to withstand the loads likely to be imposed with the required factor of safety,
be free of knots or splices except for terminal eye-splices,
be suitable for the purpose for which they are used,
be protected from abrasion or other damage from the work environment,
be secured to the platform and to an anchorage able to withstand the loads likely to be imposed on them,
be of sufficient length to lower the work platform to a safe lower landing, and
except for load lines, be used exclusively for suspending the work platform.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Cornice hooks, parapet clamps and thrust-out beams must be secured by tiebacks to a solid anchor on the building or structure.
Tiebacks for cornice hooks, parapet clamps and thrust-out beams must, as nearly as is practicable, be rigged at right angles to the building face.
Each cornice hook, parapet clamp, hanger or stirrup used to support a swing stage must be manufactured of mild steel or other material having similar ductile properties.
Counterweights must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: made of solid material not subject to loss of weight through attrition, and
secured to the thrust-out beam.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following must be constructed, installed and used in accordance with the instructions of a professional engineer:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bracing for a scaffold, if the scaffold is enclosed by a tarpaulin or any other cover;
a scaffold exceeding 38 m (125 ft) in height;
a scaffold exceeding 25 m (80 ft) in height, if stairways are included as part of the scaffold;
a scaffold used to support a temporary floor;
a scaffold used to support a crane or hoist, other than a scaffold used to support a manually powered crane or manually powered hoist;
a scaffold suspended or cantilevered from a structure;
a scaffold system supported by a catenary line;
a needle beam scaffold;
an outrigger scaffold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Permanent powered platforms must be constructed, installed and used in accordance with the instructions of a professional engineer.
If a boat is used as a work platform in a pile driving operation, a professional engineer must certify the integrity of the boat for this purpose.
A signed copy of the engineer's instructions or certification referred to in subsections (1) to (3) must be available at the workplace during installation, disassembly and use of the system.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A work platform must be removed from service until certified safe for use by the manufacturer or a professional engineer if it has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: been subjected to a sudden drop,
been in contact with exposed energized electrical equipment or conductors, or
shows signs of any kind of structural or mechanical damage or substantial wear.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that scaffolds used by workers are in a safe condition and are able to withstand the load, regardless of who erected the scaffold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The platform of each scaffold must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be a minimum nominal width of 50 cm (20 in), except that a nominal 30 cm (12 in) wide work platform may be used with ladder jacks, pump jack or similar systems,
not leave more than one opening in the work platform, which must be no greater than 25 cm (10 in) in width, and
if not level, be designed to ensure adequate footing for workers using the platform.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Guardrails may be omitted from the edge of a work platform if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the platform is adjacent to a structure that provides protection equivalent to guardrails, and
the open space between the platform and the structure is equal to or less than 30 cm (12 in).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Major components of scaffolds must be used in accordance with technical data provided by the manufacturer, or in writing by a professional engineer, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: shows the rated load, erection procedures and compliance with an applicable standard under section 13.2, and
is available at the workplace for reference.

bcl:section.bcl:text: All lumber used to construct a scaffold must be graded and marked to the National Lumber Grades Authority Standard Grading Rules for Canadian Lumber.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A scaffold must be erected with the vertical members plumb, and with the ledgers and bearers level.
The base of a scaffold must have bearing plates or sills that rest on a solid surface and are sufficient to support the weight of the scaffold.
The poles, legs and uprights of a scaffold must be securely and rigidly braced to prevent movement.
A scaffold must be effectively guyed or secured to a building or structure

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the height of the scaffold exceeds 3 times its minimum base dimension, or
in any other circumstances if required for stability.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise specified by the manufacturer, height adjustment devices must not extend more than 2/3 of their total length or 60 cm (24 in), whichever is less.

bcl:section.bcl:text: All connections between the parts of a scaffold must be secure.
A scaffold must be effectively grounded if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is a metal scaffold and is located close to a high voltage energized electrical conductor or equipment, and
a hazardous level of electrical charge is likely to be induced in the scaffold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following equipment must be clearly marked with a rated capacity:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a platform that is suspended from or attached to a crane or hoist;
an elevating work platform;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2012, App. D, s. 1.]
a swing stage;
interchangeable load bearing components of a suspended work platform system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The rated load for allowable thrust-out beam projections must be clearly marked on a thrust-out beam.
A swing stage platform, counterweight and hoist unit must each be clearly marked with their own weight.
A work platform that is suspended from a crane or hoist or attached to a crane boom must be marked with the weight of the platform and rigging and the rated capacity.
For each elevating work platform in use at a workplace,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment manufacturer's operation manual must be available at the workplace, and
the equipment manufacturer's maintenance manual, containing maintenance instructions and replacement part information, must be reasonably available to workers at the workplace.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If either of the manuals required by subsection (1) is not available, the equipment must not be used until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the manual is obtained, or
written instructions for the safe operation and maintenance of the equipment are supplied by a professional engineer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must keep records of inspection, maintenance, repair or modification that meet the requirements of Part 4 (General Conditions) for each

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: elevating work platform,
swing stage, and
permanent powered platform.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the inspection and maintenance records, other than pre-shift inspections, are not available, the equipment must not be used until it has been inspected and certified safe for use by the manufacturer or a professional engineer.
A vehicle-mounted elevating work platform and a self-propelled boom-supported elevating work platform must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: inspected in accordance with good engineering practice at least every 12 months, and
certified in writing by the equipment manufacturer or a professional engineer as complying with this Part and safe for use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 312/2012, App. C, s. 1.]
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 243/2006, s. 6.]

If a movable work platform on wheels is not designed for or intended to be moved along the floor or other supporting surface while a person is occupying the platform, the platform must be secured to prevent that movement before a person accesses or occupies the platform.

If a movable work platform is designed for and intended to be moved along the floor or other supporting surface while a person is occupying the platform, the platform must be moved only in the manner and under the conditions specified by the platform's manufacturer.
Despite subsection (2), if the height of the work platform of a rolling scaffold that is occupied by a person is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not more than one and one half times the least base dimension of the scaffold, the scaffold may be moved by the effort of the person occupying the platform or by the effort of a person on the floor or other supporting surface,
more than one and one half times the least base dimension of the scaffold, the scaffold must be moved only by the effort of a person on the floor or other supporting surface, and
more than two times the least base dimension of the scaffold, the scaffold must not be moved while the person is occupying the platform.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warning devices on elevating work platforms

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An elevating work platform, except a vehicle-mounted work platform, must have a warning system consisting of an intermittent horn or flashing light that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is automatically activated during any motion of the work platform, and
can be seen or heard by other workers in proximity to the work platform.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the safe operation of an elevating work platform requires its carrier vehicle to be on a level surface or level within specified degrees, the platform must be fitted, as the carrier requires, with a device to warn the operator that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the carrier is not level, or
the carrier is outside the permitted degrees from level.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The controls for an elevating work platform must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be clearly identified to indicate their functions,
be "hold-to-run" (continuous pressure) type that return to the neutral or the stop position when released,
be protected against inadvertent operation,
for each set of controls, be provided with an emergency stop device that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within easy reach of the operator,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include a clearly marked overriding lowering control that will enable a worker at the lower controls to stop and lower the platform in an emergency.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cranes and hoists used to suspend work platforms

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The weight of a work platform suspended from a crane or hoist or attached to a crane boom and its rigging, plus the rated capacity, must not exceed 50% of the rated capacity of the crane or hoist at the working radius or configuration.
If a work platform attached to a crane boom causes eccentric loading on the boom,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the effect on the rated capacity of the crane must be determined and the rated capacity certified by the crane manufacturer or a professional engineer, and
the rated capacity of the crane must be reduced accordingly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The boom of a crane used to suspend a work platform must have a powered boom or a fixed boom.
A work platform must not be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: suspended from an articulating boom crane, or
attached to an articulating boom crane, unless the crane manufacturer approves the installation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If workers are on a work platform suspended from a crane, a secondary hoisting line on the crane must not be used.
A crane or hoist used to raise a work platform on a load line must be equipped with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a device to prevent two-blocking at all points, or
in the case of a lattice boom crane, a two-blocking warning device.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), a work procedure acceptable to the Board may be followed to minimize the risk of two-blocking if it is not practicable to maintain a two-blocking prevention or warning device on a conventional lattice boom crane used for pile driving and similar applications.
Cranes, winches and other devices used for hoisting and lowering movable work platforms must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be operated as slowly as practicable while supporting the work platform,
be lowered under power, if the device is powered, and
not be equipped with a free running boom or hoisting winch controlled only by brakes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a movable work platform is suspended from a crane, winch or other device over a structure that cannot safely support its weight or if other hazards exist below the platform, lower limit travel devices compatible with the hoist system must be used to ensure the platform cannot be lowered beyond the safe lower limit of travel.

If the lower limit travel devices required by subsection (2) are not practicable, the employer must ensure that work procedures acceptable to the Board are used that will minimize the risk of the platform going beyond the safe lower limit of travel.
A trial lift for a work platform suspended from or attached to a crane or hoist must be performed at all work locations before the platform is occupied.
In this section, work platform means a movable work platform that is supported by a lift truck.
A work platform may be used to support workers only if other conventional means of access for the task, such as ladders, scaffolds and elevating work platforms, are not practicable.
An employer must ensure that a work platform intended for use by workers was designed, and is used by workers, in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ANSI/ITSDF B56.1-2009, Safety Standard for Low Lift and High Lift Trucks, if the platform is being used with a high lift truck as defined in Part IV of that standard, or
ANSI/ITSDF B56.6-2011, Safety Standard for Rough Terrain Forklift Trucks, if the platform is being used with a rough terrain forklift truck as defined in section 2 of that standard.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The employer must ensure that a work platform intended for use by workers is legibly marked in a conspicuous place to show

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the manufacturer of the platform, or
the professional engineer who certified the platform as having been built to meet the applicable standard referred to in subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the platform was built by a manufacturer,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the model number and serial number, or
other unique marking or identification that links the platform with the manufacturer's documentation respecting the platform's design and use,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the platform was custom built, the unique identification number or code that links the platform with the professional engineer's documentation for the platform's design and use,
the title of the safety standard or standards the platform was designed to meet,
the weight of the platform when the platform is empty,
the rated load of the platform, and

the minimum width, as measured in accordance with subsection (5), and the minimum rated capacity a lift truck must have to support the platform in a manner that complies with the applicable standard in subsection (3) when the platform is loaded to its rated load.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The width of a lift truck referred to in subsection (4) (g) must be measured in a straight line from any point on the outer part of the right load bearing tire to the corresponding point on the outer part of the left load bearing tire.
The employer must ensure that a qualified person inspects both the work platform and the lift truck supporting the work platform

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each time the platform is mounted on the lift truck, and
at the start of each work shift, if the platform is already mounted on the lift truck at the start of the work shift,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: to ensure the platform is properly secured to the lift truck and the lift truck and the platform are safe for use.
The employer must ensure that the inspections referred to in subsection (6) take place before either the work platform or the lift truck is used by a worker.
Only a worker who is qualified and authorized by the employer may operate a work platform, and the lift truck supporting the work platform, for the purpose of supporting workers on the platform.
A worker must not operate either a work platform or the lift truck supporting the work platform unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is effective two-way voice communication between the lift truck operator and a worker on the platform who is designated by the employer to provide the lift truck operator with directions for platform movement, and

the lift truck operator and the designated worker on the platform prearrange hand and arm signals, if the voice communication referred to in paragraph (a) relies on the use of a radio or other electronic system, to allow the designated worker to signal the lift truck operator to bring the platform to the ground or floor level in the event the radio or other electronic system fails.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A lift truck operator must remain at the controls of the lift truck at all times there are any workers on the platform supported by the lift truck.

Before a work platform may be used to support workers, the lift truck operator must conduct a trial lift of the platform, with no workers on the platform, to assess the suitability of the surface bearing the weight of the lift truck and whether the platform is clear of all obstructions, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the lift truck is on a type of surface the employer has identified as capable of safely supporting the lift truck and the platform when the platform is loaded to its rated load, and
the space in and around which the platform is to be raised is clear of all obstructions.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a portable powered platform is raised and lowered by two or more separately controlled hoists operated by one person on the platform, the controls must be located so that they can be used simultaneously by that person.

Before a swing stage, boatswain's chair or portable powered platform is used in any of the following circumstances, a professional engineer must have certified in writing that the design, installation and proposed use of the swing stage, boatswain's chair or portable powered platform, as the case may be, meets the requirements of CSA Standard CAN/CSA Z271-10 Safety code for suspended platforms and CSA Standard CAN/CSA Z91-02 (R2008) Health and Safety Code for Suspended Equipment Operations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one work platform will be used above or below any portion of another work platform,
a deck or planking will be used to span a gap between two independent work platforms,
the work platform will exceed 10 m (32 ft) in length, or
the suspension height will exceed 91 m (300 ft).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person on an elevating work platform must wear a personal fall arrest system secured to a suitable and substantial anchorage point.

Despite subsection (1), a person on a scissor lift, or on an elevating work platform with similar characteristics to a scissor lift, that is on a firm level surface with no irregularities to cause platform instability, is exempt from wearing a personal fall arrest system, provided that all manufacturer's guardrails and chains are in place.

If a person is supported on a work platform suspended by fewer than four suspension lines, the person must use a personal fall arrest system secured to an anchor meeting the requirements of Part 11 [Fall Protection] and independent of the work platform and its suspension system.

If a person is supported on a work platform suspended by four or more suspension lines, the person must use a personal fall arrest system secured to an anchor on the platform or to an anchor meeting the requirements of Part 11 [Fall Protection] and independent of the work platform and its suspension system.
Despite subsection (3), a person is not required to use a personal fall protection system on an outrigger or suspended mason's scaffold with guardrails on the open sides.
Each person on a work platform suspended from a crane or hoist must use a personal fall arrest system with a shock absorbing lanyard, secured to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an anchor above the load hook, or

an anchor attached to the platform and designated for that purpose by the manufacturer or a professional engineer, provided that the platform has a safety strap that will prevent the platform from falling more than 15 cm (6 in) if the platform becomes dislodged from the hook.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each person on a work platform attached to a crane boom must use a personal fall arrest system secured to an anchor on the boom or on the platform.
The personal fall arrest system referred to in subsection (5) must be secured on the boom or on the platform to an anchor that is designated by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the manufacturer, or
a professional engineer.
